Please snr can you do a tutorial on moment of forces
When the block is floating we don't calculate tension force why
In the first problem there is no tension on the block of ice, so why do we calculate the tension?

An astronaut of 60 k.g weight on earth takes off vertically in a spaceship reaches a speed of 2000 km/hr in2 min ;what is his aparent weight during this time ? Reply first fully solved or send me a pic my no.7039980370

Force = mass × gravity = volume × density × gravity. So the ship in water has displacement of 10000 tonnes. This is his mass, not weight. But since ship and water are in same gravity field we can use mass as force to calculate ship moment. Moment = force × distance. Distance is GM value od 2 meters. So moment is 10000 × 2 = 20000 tm. Should ship deadweight be deadmass? Or should we express deadweight in newtons to be correct? Ship loads 200t container ion board. Is 200t mass or weight? Why do all books say weight? Thank you.
How can you keep uploading Videos on this frequency you Do?
yeah i'm confused by this too. please let us know!

The tension force in the video is just an illustration of what apparent weight is. The apparent weight equals to the tension force that is needed to make the block static (net force=0). Hope that helps.

Whenever we multiply acceleration due to gravity with the mass it gives us the gravitational force which we usually call weight of the object....your question is difficult to read can you please be more specific.....

Many times, terms were already in use in common vernacular before scientists came up with a more precise definition. Weight and mass definitely have this problem. The term weight existed before the idea of mass existed. Likely, ship deadweight is actually deadmass. At least, based on how you are explaining moment. A ton is 1,000 kg so the ship is displacing 10,000,000 kg. As you said, this is mass apparenly.  The unit for moment should be Newton meters. I still don't know why moment is calculated with kg/tonnes and not Newtons. This suggests that it actually a deadmass and not a deadweight. I don't think it has to do with a constant gravitational field. I think you can get away with using mass for weight because of water's buoyancy. But I can't explain the math that supports that argument.
